column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Stamenković et al found oxygen levels throughout
#Text=Mars would be high enough for the least demanding aerobic ( oxygen-using ) microbes , for all the brines they considered , and all the methods of calculation .

#Text=They published a detailed map [ 3 ] of the distributions of solubility for calcium perchlorates for their more optimistic calculations , which they reckoned were closer to the true case , with and without supercooling .
#Text=The lowest concentrations were shown in the tropical southern uplands .
#Text=Brine in regions poleward of about 67.5 °to the north and about 72.5 °to the south could have oxygen concentrations high enough for simple sponges .
#Text=Closer to the poles , concentrations could go higher , approaching levels typical of sea water on Earth , 0.2 moles per cubic meter ( 6.4 mg per liter ) , for calcium perchlorates .

#Text=On Earth , worms and clams that live in the muddy sea beds require 1 mg per liter , bottom feeders such as crabs and oysters 3 mg per liter , and spawning migratory fish 6 mg per liter , all within 0.2 moles per cubic meter , 6.4 mg per liter .

#Text=( ( Wikinews ) ) Does your paper 's value of up to 0.2 moles of oxygen per cubic meter , the same as Earth 's sea water , mean that there could potentially be life on Mars as active as our sea worms or even fish ?
#Text=Stamenković : Mars is such a different place than the Earth and we still need to do so much more work before we can even start to speculate .
#Text=Stamenković et al studied magnesium and calcium perchlorates , common on Mars .
#Text=They found the highest oxygen concentrations occur when the water is colder , which happens most in polar regions .
#Text=( ( WN ) )

#Text=The temperatures for the highest levels of oxygen are really low , -133°C , so , is the idea that this oxygen would be retained when the brines warm up to more habitable temperatures during the day or seasonally ?
#Text=Or would the oxygen be lost as it warms up ?

#Text=Or — is the idea that it has to be some exotic biochemistry that works only at ultra low temperatures like Dirk Schulze-Makuch 's life based on hydrogen peroxide and perchlorates internal to the cells as antifreeze ?
#Text=Stamenković :
#Text=The options are both : first , cool oxygen-rich environments do not need to be habitats .
#Text=They could be reservoirs packed with a necessary nutrient that can be accessed from a deeper and warmer region .
#Text=Second , the major reason for limiting life at low temperature is ice nucleation , which would not occur in the type of brines that we study .
#Text=Varying tilt of Mars 's axis over hundreds of thousands to millions of years .
#Text=The current situation is a 25-degree tilt ( top left ) .
#Text=Image : NASA / JPL - Caltech .
#Text=Stamenković et al 's paper is theoretical and is based on a simplified general circulation model of the Mars atmosphere — it ignores distinctions of seasons and the day / night cycle .
#Text=Stamenković 's team combined it with a chemical model of how oxygen would dissolve in the brines and used this to predict oxygen levels in such brines at various locations on Mars .
